ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Graph Neural Networks, Scalability, Explainability, Graph Generation and Graph Transformers

Deep learning basic 
Graph deep learning theory
embedding theory
A broad survey of information about graph neural networks: message passing, graph convolutional networks, graph transformers, isomorphism, expressiveness, spectral GNNs, and many more.

I developed knowledge of deep learning for not only graphs, but the basics of deep learning as well. The class is very cutting edge -- the professor researches graph neural networks himself, and I've been introduced to a lot of new content and research papers.

GNN basics - message passing, dataset splitting, common losses, evaluation metrics, node/edge/graph level prediction heads and tasks. Graph attention, graph transformers (graphormer), GNNExplainer, GIN, GNN theory (computation trees, expressiveness), PyG, knowledge graphs, hyperbolic embeddings. If you put the time in, it's enough for you to feel comfortable reading most papers in graph learning.

I've learned about graphs and graph-specific algorithms used to tackle problems with an underlying graph structure. This course helped me build both a basic mathematical understanding about these problem, as well as a programming foundation on implementing such solutions with PyTorch.
State-of-the-art ML techniques for graphs. The strengths, weaknesses, and challenges of said techniques.
Good survey of GNNs
The use and applications of Deep Learning for graph-structured data.
A breadth of theory in graph learning methods
Graph learning skills
Basics and application of different GNN related techniques.
understanding about neural networks, graph neural networks, and machine learning. so many things in our life depend on and work with graph neural networks so it was very valuable to learn
GNN
I learned how to use graph neural networks and implement a hands-on project
deep learning on graph-structured data
Graph deep learning
Learned about various GNN architectures, how to scale up graph learning, transformers, and gained coding skills in python.
Graph neural networks
message passing neural networks, graph transformers
Skills to conduct machine learning research, especially graph.
Theory and hand-on experience of GNN.
I gained an enormous amount of knowledge about a wide range of state-of-the-art methods in graph-based deep learning.
deep learning stuff but with graphs. I think im more interested in this field after taking the class
a lot about graph and dl.
I get know about the field of graph-based deep learning, and the history of the field's development, up to many cutting-edge models.
The understanding of GNN architectures.
Graphs, SGD, transformers, RNNS, explainability, difficulties that come with having data as a graph.
Wide array of GNN topics from graph processing to GNN architectures
Basic concepts, advanced knowledge, and coding ability in the field of Graph-based deep learning.
I learned an overview of many state-of-the-art deep learning methods for graph-based data. I also learned basic coding methods using PyTorch and PyTorch Geometric.
I have improved my knowledge of GNN and related neural network models. I also improved a lot in coding and project management skills.

Node/link/edge prediction, various types of GNNs (GraphSage, GCNs, GATs), fields of application (knowledge graphs, biological datasets), various objectives, learning types (unsupervised vs supervised), loss functions (e.g. cross entropy), embeddings
a big picture understanding of the current areas of research on deep learning w/ graphas
An overview of graph deep learning.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Too much workload and content, so many papers to study and understand different topics, there was no reason to cover so many things, he did not concentrate on basic stuff. In each lesson, a different topic was introduced and the explanation was not so intuitive and expainable.
There is too much information in one lecture and too fast to keep up.

The course is quite interesting and new. I think this area will be prosperity in the future and I'd love to know more about it
Too many knowledge points for a one semester course, can't go deeper into the models
There is little correlation between HW and course knowledge, I can still finish them if I didn't know much about the course.
The coding assignments can't keep up with course progress.

This course is definitely more about breadth than depth. Much, much more material is covered in lecture than is ever used in assignments - this made it feel a bit difficult for me to truly understand some of the more complicated points of each lecture, since we would never explore them in any concrete way. The material itself is fascinating - I'm beginning to try and frame every machine learning problem in a graph structure!

There is pretty good staff support, but every single homework contained errors that were later corrected - the homeworks are usually released late anyways, so this quickly becomes frustrating. I imagine this will improve through future iterations of the course as the material becomes a bit more solidified.
The course is very well taught and the slides are very clear. You could learn the content almost purely based off the slides, and the Psets teach you as you do them.

Strengths: Prof. Ying is a great lecturer and extremely bright. The lecture slides are really well put together and easy to understand. The assignments and colabs are graded generously, which helps you stress less about them and focus more on learning. Overall really great class, no cons.

Strengths: This is a state-of-the-art course, as it covers graph structured deep learning techniques, which are increasingly useful in today's AI domain. Also, it is a big plus that it offers both a mathematical and a (basic) programming understanding for these. Furthermore, I think that it includes information about almost everything in this Graph-AI area, offering an opportunity for someone to dig in if they want to.

Weaknesses: As it covers almost everything under the sun for this Graph-AI domain, it offers very little information and insights on each subsection, making it very difficult to follow through and understand in depth. It would be better if the syllabus was reduced a bit more, so that the more "important" sections are covered better and more in depth, while limiting the more "advanced" sections in only a couple of classes. Also, as the size of the workload was especially large, it was hard to understand every thing that was asked, while struggling to complete the assignments in time.
Reduce the amount of content by ~20%. Respond to Ed discussion posts (especially leading up to the final exam!). Focus on a handful of concepts rather than trying to cover every recent advancement.

Prof is super knowledgeable, independent project is definitely a plus since you get hands-on experience, lectures, content, and class overall are well-organized. Lectures are dry at times. I think having two midterms each covering half of the material instead of one final covering everything could have encouraged me to keep up more with the lectures, since homework usually doesnt require lecture knowledge. I wish final tested knowledge more instead of being mostly brute force computation.
It is an excellent course. I just think that the last coding assignment was much more challenging than the previous ones for a student without a CS background like myself.

Lectures are thorough, but for some topics (especially early in the semester) it was difficult to understand how they all fit together.
Problem sets are helpful for understanding the material, but they could have started sooner. Some topics were covered by lecture weeks ahead of homework practice.
The course exam was substantially longer than the previous year's, but I gather that the course continues to improve with each offering.
Reasonable coverage and depth of a lot of topics!
Good enough
The content of the course is very useful
It's very good overall
Too fast, too much thing on the slides.
Problem sets were engaging and fun. Coding assignments were a bit too easy, but I also didn't know if I could code harder things. I wish I had developed my coding skills more in this course.
The slides can be made a bit more interactive.
good content

Strength: very up-to-date and novel
Weakness: too many topics to cover and not all topics are discussed in depth. Pacing is a bit too fast

Strengths: very useful, reasonable workload, suitable for GNN beginners.
Weaknesses: To many content and slides in each lecture and some overlap between. I hope they can be distilled and have a summary or review section to get the overall logic of the course.

This is an excellent course! It covers a huge amount of material, all of which is highly relevant to the current state of the field, and the assignments are structured such that they reinforce the concepts from class without putting an enormous workload on the students. I found that the homework assignments and colabs complemented each other nicely, and I think this was a good structure overall. I liked that the course was based around a final project, as this encouraged real-world applications of the concepts we had discussed in class. The lectures moved quite quickly, but I actually think this was a good thing, since it allowed for much more content to be covered in the course, and the availability of the lecture recordings allowed for students to go back over things they may not have fully absorbed the first time. My only real critique was the use of a closed-book final exam: I certainly understand the necessity of having a final exam to encourage students to review all of the material, but since in any real situation students will have access to notes, at the very least I think an in-person, closed-Internet, open-book final would be more relevant.
I liked it and i liked how chill the workload is while material still super interesting
contents are very useful, but the teaching skills can be improved.
The lectures are very well organized, but sometimes the pace was a bit too fast.
The written assignment is not very related to the course materials taught in class.

Strengths: the material is really interesting, and Rex does a great job of explaining why certain methods have been developed and how everything connects to each other. As a non CS major who doesn't like too much theory, I actually found the hw assignments to be pretty chill and mostly doable on my own. Also, the slides are amazing and have all of the material he talks about so you don't really need to take notes. Weaknesses: there is SO much material its crazy, and he has to go extremely fast through the slides. He said the final was lightweight but you definitely need to study a lot since there is so much material. The good thing is I think he grades chill.
Organized, low-stress environment which encouraged learning
There's too much content in the course

The concepts are super interesting and cutting-edge, as they are directly taken from cutting-edge research papers. However, this also means the concepts can feel a bit scattered, and Prof. Ying throws a lot of miscellaneous papers/concepts at you without diving too deeply into any single one.
It offered a very comprehensive map of GNN related knowledge, many of which are relatively new and up-to-date.

This course covers a lot of topics in graph learning, and it can be challenging to follow the entire lecture. The written and coding assignment help me to understand the course material and TA office hours are very helpful.

Strength: course doesn't require lots of prior ML experience (lectures review ML concepts), PPTs are very well organized, Professor Ying is a pioneer in the field, GNNs are a very modern and relevant topic in industry, final project is great for cumulative understanding

Weakness: PPTs are on the longer side, so lectures may feel rushed at times

Strengths: all the material is broken down into digestible and engaging graphics. all lectures recorded and available on zoom  

Weaknesses: i didn't learn anything about coding from this class at all (more of a theoretical class). Also grading was inconsistent w/ the HWs

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I do not think so due to the enormous workload that you need to face if you register to this class. The workload should be decreased and focused on the main concept of Graph Neural Networks.
Yes. I learned a lot. But it is also too hard.
Yes, the course's material is worth to study in depth

I would only recommend this course to someone very experienced with graph convolutional networks already. The course moved extremely fast and I think it would have been better if the professor just covered a few less topics and paced the course more.
If you are interested in graphs as a data structure and have had little exposure to GNNs, this is for you!

Yes! This class is cutting edge and you will definitely learn a lot from taking this class, stuff that was only created maybe a few years ago. If you are doing anything machine learning related, graph neural networks opens up a whole lot more possibilities.
Definitely

Yes, I'd recommend this course, given its importance in the current AI domain and the state-of-the-art sections it covers. However, I think that the student can only receive a basic understanding of everything that is being covered in this class, and that for better understanding they really need to do research on their own.

It's hard to say. Although Rex is brilliant, and the content is fantastic, this course is frustrating. The lectures are dense, the assignments are scattered, and the expectations are unclear. But it still may be worth it, just because the content is so good.

Depends. Good survey of GNNs and knowledgeable prof, so def useful if you want to do ai research. However, feel like knowledge learned here is highly specific with little generalizability to other areas of cs.

Absolutely. Cutting-edge techniques are taught in an environment that facilitates learning, with challenging homeworks,, assignments and a final project to demonstrate the progress made throughout the semester.
Absolutely, this is a fascinating subject taught by a leader in the field.
The material is interesting, but the course is decently backloaded.
yes.
yes. just start the term project early
Good introduction
Yes, it has writing homework and colab assignments that can help us understand the content better
Yes, interesting materials, insightful coding homework
Yes, the contents are important.

I would. This class is what you make of it. You can learn a ton if you want, you could also get by just understanding the basics probably.

This course is also probably better taken as a second AI/ML course. I'd recommend many students to take it because it covers a field of ML that isn't really taught in other courses, and it does so in a very very thorough manner.
Yes
good overview of deep learning on graphs
Yes, it is useful.
Recommend, the materials will be useful if you want to do research in the area.
Yes. Even for student like me who are not from a SC background can get a thorough understanding of GNN through this course.

I would absolutely recommend this course! It's highly comprehensive and extremely modern-- I'm confident that the material two years from now will be significantly different from what was covered this year, and that's a good thing which speaks to the fast-moving pace of AI research overall. Anyone with an interest in graph-based ML could not have a better course for getting up to speed on a wide variety of methods and applications. My only caution would be that students should have a genuine interest in the topic -- the course necessitates spending time carefully thinking through the (fairly complex) subject matter, so someone who isn't actually interested may not enjoy that aspect.
yes take it rex is cool dude and grades chill you'll learn as much as you want and its not stressful
The course topics are very interesting and the lectures are highly organized -- but the pace could sometimes be a bit fast.
I do not recommend this course for students who have not taken any deep learning classes before.

Definitely would recommend. I'm not a CS major and didn't meet too many of the prereqs, but I enjoyed the assignments and the material was engaging since it covered so many new topics. I feel like this would be a much more enjoyable class than Deep Learning with Applications, since it also covers deep learning but is not as difficult. The only thing I would say is plan your time because the class ended a little hectic.
Sure, great way to learn about processing graph data

Yes. If you are vaguely interested in deep learning, I think this is a cool intro survey course on various topics; however, if you are looking for a more structured and rigorous approach to deep learning, I would consider taking the other introductory courses instead. The course takes on very complicated concepts, but feeds them to you in a very surface-level and basic manner-- the lectures seem very scary, but the problem sets often end up being basic matrix multiplication and the coding assignments are very short.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student who wants to get a taste of GNN and know about the basics of GNN-related deep learning models.

Yes, even if you haven't taken an introductory ML course, Deep Learning and GNNs are a great step into modern industry applications of neural networks and their potential to solve newer types of problems by leveraging properties of graph data.

Yes! Easy to get a good grade so you can focus as much (or as little......) as you want on genuinely learning. All the support systems (OH, ed discussion, extra readings) are there to help you w/ however far you go
Yes, this is a great course accessible to most people and light on the workload. Good for an overview of methods, and has a final project to dive deeper into a topic thats interesting to you.
